title: ğŸ‰ Welcome to Graph Learning!
content: This interactive graph teaches you how to understand and work with graphs. A graph is simply nodes (things) connected by edges (relationships). We'll cover common structures and advanced patterns like cliques, bipartite graphs, weighted paths, and centrality.

title: ğŸ Start Here: Profile
content: Click this node to see the three main branches: Basics, Structures, and Interactions. Use search to jump aroundâ€”try 'Path Node 1' or 'Clique A1'.

title: ğŸ“š Graph Basics: Foundation
content: Nodes, edges, direction, weights, and labels. We will also demonstrate: cliques (fully connected groups), bipartite partitions, community structure, and measures like centrality (hub detection).

title: ğŸ” Try the Search Feature
content: Open the menu and search for Path Node 1 or Clique A1. Search zooms and focuses results so you can inspect specific patterns quickly.

title: ğŸ—‚ï¸ Graph Structures Hub
content: This hub points to many structures. Hover 'Graph Structures' then click different structure nodes to focus examples: Trees, Stars, DAGs, Cycles, Bipartite, Cliques, Communities, and Weighted Paths.

title: ğŸŒ³ Tree: Hierarchy
content: Root â†’ Branch â†’ Leaf. Use for clear parent-child classification (org charts, categories). Click the example nodes and follow the path down.

title: â­ Star & Centrality
content: Hub nodes have high centralityâ€”many direct connections. Look at 'Centrality: High Degree Node' and see how hubs connect across communities.

title: ğŸ“‹ DAG: Dependencies
content: Directed, acyclic flows used for build graphs and task pipelines. Follow Task A â†’ B/C â†’ D to see how dependencies compose.

title: ğŸ”„ Cycle: Feedback Loop
content: Loops can be desired (feedback) or problematic (circular dependencies). Find the cycle nodes and hover to see how the loop closes.

title: ğŸ§© Bipartite Graphs & Matching
content: Two partitions connect only across sets. Search for 'Bip Left 1' and 'Bip Right 1'â€”practice forming matches (applicantsâ†”jobs). Bipartite graphs power recommendations and matching systems.

title: ğŸ”º Cliques & Communities
content: Cliques are fully connected groups. Communities are dense subgraphs with sparse cross-links. Find 'Clique A1' and 'Community A1' to explore both patterns.

title: ğŸ” Shortest Path & Weighted Edges
content: Use the path example (Path Node 1 â†’ Path Node 4) to compare weighted routes. Lower-weight edges make a route more attractive when finding shortest paths.

title: ğŸ’¡ Centrality & Influence
content: Central nodes are critical for information flow. Click the 'Centrality' node to see how it connects multiple areasâ€”the hub is a single point of failure but also a powerful lever.

title: ğŸ¯ Apply What You Learned
content: Try the tasks: match bipartite pairs, identify cliques/communities, find the shortest path, and pick which model best fits a problem in the real world.

title: âœ¨ Wrap-up
content: You've now seen richer structures and learned how to inspect them with the UI. Complete the exercises for hands-on practice. Happy graphing!
